{'text': 'Los Angeles (CNN) -- The defense anesthesiology expert in the trial of Michael Jackson\'s doctor was found in contempt of court Wednesday for referring to his private talks with Dr. Conrad Murray during his testimony.\n\n\n\n\n\nDr. Murray did not testify in his own defense in his involuntary manslaughter trial and the judge refused to allow Dr. Paul White to base any of his testimony on anything other than what Murray told police.\n\n\n\n\n\nLos Angeles County Superior Court Judge Michael Pastor gave Dr. White 30 days to pay a $250 fine, but he also dropped a second contempt citation for derogatory comments he allegedly made about a rival witness.\n\n\n\n\n\nWednesday\'s contempt hearing was part of the aftermath of Dr. Murray\'s involuntary manslaughter that ended with a guilty verdict last week.\n\n\n\n\n\nAnother contempt hearing is set for November 29, the day Murray is set to be sentenced, for one of the defense lawyers who allegedly violated the judge\'s gag order by speaking to NBC\'s "Today Show" during the trial.\n\n\n\n\n\nMurray defense lawyer Michael Flanagan, who was in court to defend Dr. White Wednesday, said after the hearing that he believed Murray should be eligible for early release if he is given prison time.\n\n\n\n\n\nA California law that took effect last month provides for non-violent state inmates to be assigned to county jails to relieve state prison overcrowding. The Los Angeles County jail has a court-ordered early release program to relieve overcrowding, which allows non-violent offenders to serve much of their sentences at home with electronic monitoring.\n\n\n\n\n\nFlanagan said Murray is not a safety threat to the public and should be included in the early release program.\n\n\n\n\n\nDr. White told reporters after the hearing that he still believed Jackson gave himself the overdose of the surgical anesthetic propofol and a sedative the coroner ruled killed the pop icon.\n\n\n\n\n\n"I was aware that Michael Jackson had self-administered drugs in the past, propofol specifically, and so what\'s to say that he wouldn\'t do it again," White said. "He was desperate. Murray was withholding from him the drug that he desperately desired."\n\n\n\n\n\nWhite, while under cross-examination by Deputy District Attorney David Walgren, referred several times to his private discussions with Dr. Murray about what happened the day Jackson died. Judge Pastor repeatedly warned him not to do so.\n\n\n\n\n\nFinally, the judge cited White for contempt and set Wednesday\'s hearing to decide if he would be fined.\n\n\n\n\n\n"There wasn\'t any intentional deception here or violation of the court order," defense lawyer Michael Flanagan told Pastor Wednesday. "He was explaining to Mr. Walgren \'Hey, I can\'t answer that.\'"\n\n\n\n\n\nProsecutor Walgren, who has grown a beard since the televised trial ended, told the judge that this was one of "multiple instances" where Dr. White was "trying to sabotage the trial."\n\n\n\n\n\n"It was intentional and deliberate," Walgren said. "It was an attempt to deny the people a fair trial."\n\n\n\n\n\nWhite told the judge he "did my best as I was admonished by you to answer question truthfully and as completely as I could."\n\n\n\n\n\n"I apologize profusely if I disrespected you," White said. "I learned a lot from this experience."\n\n\n\n\n\nPastor ruled that White was guilty of violating his order by giving "a non-responsive answer" that dealt with "no-go territory."\n\n\n\n\n\nWhile he could have fined him $1,000, he only imposed a $250 fine. Judge Pastor also dropped the other contempt charge which stemmed from an online report that quoted White allegedly calling prosecution anesthesiology expert Dr. Steven Shafer "a scumbag."', 'qa': [{'question': 'What did the defence lawyer say?', 'answers': ['he believed Murray should be eligible for early release if he is given prison time.', '"There wasn\'t any intentional deception here or violation of the court order,"', 'Murray should be eligible for early release', 'he believed Murray should be eligible for early release']}, {'question': 'what did the lawyer say', 'answers': ['eligible', 'he believed Murray should be eligible for early release if he is given prison time.', 'early release', 'after the hearing that he believed Murray should be eligible for early release if he is given prison time.']}, {'question': 'Whay charge was dropped?', 'answers': ['contempt citation for derogatory comments', 'a second contempt citation for derogatory comments he allegedly made about a rival witness.']}, {'question': 'what did the prosecutor argue', 'answers': ['not a safety threat to the public', 'Dr. White was "trying to sabotage the trial."', '"multiple instances" where Dr. White was "trying to sabotage the trial."']}, {'question': 'what is the number of days he has', 'answers': ['30']}, {'question': 'What did the prosecutor argue that the expert tried to do?', 'answers': ['violating his order by giving "a non-responsive answer"', '"trying to sabotage the trial."']}, {'question': 'Who should get an early release?', 'answers': ['Dr. Conrad Murray']}, {'question': 'How much was the contempt fine?', 'answers': ['$250']}, {'question': 'How many days does paul white have to pay the fine?', 'answers': ['30']}]}
{'text': "(CNN) -- Olafur Ragnar Grimsson is currently enjoying a third term as President of the Republic of Iceland. Since first being elected in 1996, Grimsson has been a passionate advocate of international cooperation in combating climate change.\n\n\n\nOlafur Ragnar Grimsson\n\n\n\nWhilst Iceland still imports oil for its transport, electricity is generated from hydroelectric power. And heating is provided by geothermal power -- an abundant source in energy due to Iceland's geographical position sitting above two continental plates.\n\n\n\nIceland is also pioneering the use of hydrogen power with several projects testing the viability of this renewable energy.\n\n\n\nIn his youth, Grimsson studied Economics and Political Science at Manchester University, gaining a B.A. and a Ph.D before returning to Iceland to take up a post as a professor of Political Science at the University of Iceland.\n\n\n\nHe entered Althingi, the Icelandic parliament in 1978, served as minister of finance between 1988 and 1991 and was leader of the Peoples' Alliance from 1987 to 1995.\n\n\n\nGrimsson promotes the intelligent use of renewable energy resources and is providing world leaders with an invaluable insight into how their own economies might make the switch to more renewable sources of energy.", 'qa': [{'question': 'Who is president of Iceland?', 'answers': ['Olafur Ragnar Grimsson', 'Grimsson', 'Olafur', 'Ragnar Grimsson']}, {'question': 'Who is the pioneer for the group?', 'answers': ['Iceland', 'Olafur Ragnar Grimsson', 'renewable energy.']}, {'question': 'What has he called for?', 'answers': ['advocate of international cooperation in combating climate change.']}, {'question': 'Where is President of?', 'answers': ['Ragnar Grimsson is currently enjoying a third term as', 'Republic of Iceland.', 'Olafur', 'of the Republic of Iceland.']}, {'question': 'What has he been trying to organize?', 'answers': ['cooperation in combating climate change.']}, {'question': 'When did Grimsson become president?', 'answers': ['1996,', 'elected']}, {'question': 'What did he repeatedly call for?', 'answers': ['renewable energy', 'combating climate change.', 'international cooperation', 'climate change.', 'passionate advocate', 'promotes the intelligent use']}]}
{'text': '(CNN) -- It was just after midday on a cold December Monday in South Korea\'s capital when news of Kim Jong Il\'s death filtered through.\n\n\n\n\n\nThough the reclusive North Korean leader had been plagued with health problems in recent years, the announcement was greeted with general astonishment in Seoul, according to a journalist from the country\'s largest newspaper.\n\n\n\n\n\n"The initial reaction was shock, quickly followed by speculation about what was going to happen next," said Woosuk Ken Choi, assistant editor with The Chosun Daily.\n\n\n\n\n\nFor its part, the South Korean military responded by raising its alert level, while the country\'s media went into overdrive trying to predict how this oblique and erratic state would respond.\n\n\n\n\n\nBut Choi said most ordinary Koreans were remaining calm.\n\n\n\n\n\nNorth Korea: Should we fear change?\n\n\n\n\n\n"There was no rush to supermarkets to buy up food," he said in an interview with CNN. "The South Korean public seems confident that the country will be able to manage this. Many see the North Koreans as like us, people we need to care for and help."\n\n\n\n\n\nOutright conflict is not something many would expect, he added.\n\n\n\n\n\n"There is a little tradition in Korea that when someone passes away in a family you stop fighting.\n\n\n\n\n\n"We\'re on high alert not because we want to do something but because some renegade North Korean unit might cause some trouble. But no one really thinks the North Koreans will launch an attack.\n\n\n\n\n\n"Nothing happened in 1994 when Kim Il Sung died and it will be the same this time."\n\n\n\n\n\nThe architect of what became known as the Democratic People\'s Republic of Korea in 1948 after the Korean peninsula was divided between U.S. and Soviet occupation forces, Kim Il Sung was an autocratic leader who presided over a policy of Juche, or self-reliance, which did much to foster the Communist country\'s isolation.\n\n\n\n\n\nWhen Kim Jong Il, his oldest son, succeeded him, North Korea was crippled economically, having lost one of its main trading partners when the Soviet Union collapsed. Kim largely ignored the massive problems at home and focused on shoring up the regime\'s position and investing in the military as a bulwark against the wealthy, U.S.-backed south.\n\n\n\n\n\nWhat military hardware does North Korea have?\n\n\n\n\n\nBut with Kim dead, Choi believes many in the south will see this as an opportunity to improve relations with their dysfunctional neighbor, perhaps even paving the way for reunification.\n\n\n\n\n\n"Most people, whether left or right on the political spectrum, hope this is the case," he said.\n\n\n\n\n\n"However a large chunk of South Koreans do worry about the financial burden of reunification, citing the case of West and East Germany in the early 1990s.\n\n\n\n\n\n"Others argue the cost of living together will be a lot less than living separately in the long run. I also believe a whole host of issues could be resolved with reunification."\n\n\n\n\n\nBut Choi said each generation in South Korea has its own viewpoint when it comes to relations with the north.\n\n\n\n\n\n"Those in their teens and 20s have a real fear of military conflict, as they are the ones who have to complete their compulsory military service," he said.\n\n\n\n\n\n"Many people in their 30s and 40s worry about the financial cost to them of reunification, while those in their 50s and 60s back a united Korea whatever the cost."\n\n\n\n\n\nIf reunification is a pipe dream for now, Choi says there is a difference of opinion in South Korea about the dynastic succession in the north.\n\n\n\n\n\n"Many people believe the transfer of power to a third generation is absurd, totally anachronistic and not what the world is about today," he said.\n\n\n\n\n\n"But those who believe in a policy of engagement with North Korea say it doesn\'t matter whether it is third or fourth generation, they\'re still our people and we need to talk to them to try and resolve the situation."\n\n\n\n\n\nAnother view, according to Choi, is "the Great Successor" will not last long.\n\n\n\n\n\n"He\'s simply too young," he said. Kim Jong Un is believed to be in his late 20s.\n\n\n\n\n\n"There is this notion in Korean society -- north and south -- that if you take the throne too young you won\'t last long. No matter how good he is, they think his uncles and more experienced family members will rule from behind him and that he could ultimately be sacrificed."\n\n\n\n\n\nAs pictures of ordinary North Koreans mourning the loss of their Dear Leader continued to filter onto television screens across South Korea Tuesday, Choi felt most people would have been struck by how staged they seemed.\n\n\n\n\n\n"The pictures don\'t reflect the reality in North Korea," he argued.\n\n\n\n\n\n"When Kim Il Sung died there were a number of people who really went out and cried because they really did respect him.\n\n\n\n\n\n"Kim Jong Il\'s case is different because about two or three million people died of starvation after he came to power. The level of mourning will be about a tenth of what it was in 1994. This is the view of many defectors I have spoken to."', 'qa': [{'question': 'Who was greeted in Seoul?', 'answers': ['in', 'the announcement', 'announcement']}, {'question': 'What happened in 1994?', 'answers': ['Kim Il Sung died']}, {'question': 'What was the reaction of South Korean military?', 'answers': ['raising its alert level,']}, {'question': 'Who died in 1994?', 'answers': ['Kim Il Sung']}, {'question': 'When did Kim II Sung die?', 'answers': ['1994']}, {'question': 'Who says most people in the south are calm about the situation?', 'answers': ['Woosuk Ken Choi,']}, {'question': 'What level was raised?', 'answers': ['South Korean military', 'alert']}, {'question': 'What was the reaction in Seoul?', 'answers': ['general', 'shock,', 'astonishment', 'followed by speculation']}, {'question': 'There was general astonishment where?', 'answers': ['Seoul,', 'in Seoul,']}]}

{'text': 'London, England (CNN) -- A number of Latin American countries have rushed to offer their support to Argentina in its long-running territorial dispute with Britain over the Falkland Islands.\n\n\n\n\n\nThis week Britain began drilling for oil in the waters off the archipelago, despite opposition from Buenos Aires which claims sovereignty over the islands it calls Las Malvinas.\n\n\n\n\n\nThe project has reignited tensions between the two countries, who fought a brief war over the islands in 1982, with Argentine President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner accusing London of ignoring international law.\n\n\n\n\n\nArgentina says the natural resources around the islands, which lie in the South Atlantic Ocean off the Argentinean coast, should be protected, and Britain must accept international resolutions labeling the Falklands a disputed area.\n\n\n\n\n\nMexico\'s President Felipe Calderon weighed into the dispute late Monday when he said a number of countries in the region had drafted a document in support of their South American neighbor.\n\n\n\n\n\nSpeaking at a summit of Latin American leaders in the Mexican resort of Playa Del Carmen, Calderon claimed Ecuador, Chile, Guatemala, Bolivia and Venezuela had all backed Argentina\'s opposition to the drilling.\n\n\n\n\n\n"We have approved a declaration in which leaders of countries and governments present here reaffirm their support for the Republic of Argentina\'s legitimate rights in its sovereignty dispute with the United Kingdom," he said in a statement issued by Argentine officials.\n\n\n\n\n\nEcuador\'s President Rafael Correa offered his country\'s "unconditional support" to Argentina, while his Chilean counterpart Michelle Bachelet said, "We not only support our sister republic\'s claims to the Malvinas islands but every year we present its case to the United Nations\' Special Committee on Decolonization."\n\n\n\n\n\nVenezuela\'s outspoken leader Hugo Chavez also reiterated his support for Argentina. "We support unconditionally the Argentine government and the Argentine people in their complaints," Chavez told reporters Tuesday, according to Reuters.com. "That sea and that land belongs to Argentina and to Latin America."\n\n\n\n\n\nA day earlier, Chavez had used his weekly televised address to make a direct appeal to Britain\'s Queen Elizabeth II. "Look, England, how long are you going to be in Las Malvinas? Queen of England, I\'m talking to you," he said.\n\n\n\n\n\n"The time for empires are over, haven\'t you noticed? Return the Malvinas to the Argentine people."\n\n\n\n\n\nOn Monday, British oil and gas exploration company Desire Petroleum announced that its Ocean Guardian rig had started drilling an exploration well in the North Falkland Basin, some 100 kilometers (60 miles) north of the islands.\n\n\n\n\n\nDesire estimates that the North Falkland Basin could contain 3.5 billion barrels of oil as well as having "significant gas potential." The exploratory drilling is expected to last around 30 days, a spokesman for the company told CNN.\n\n\n\n\n\nBut the prospect of Britain making a highly lucrative discovery in region has infuriated Buenos Aires.\n\n\n\n\n\nThis has to do with the defense of the interests of Argentineans, not just about sovereignty," Argentine Cabinet Chief Anibal Fernandez said last week, adding that Argentina lays claim not just to the islands, but to any resources that could be found there.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn a statement last week, the Falkland Islands government, which represents its 2,500 residents, said it had "every right to develop a hydrocarbons industry within our waters."\n\n\n\n\n\n"The British government has clearly stated that they support our right to develop legitimate business," it said. {'text': '(CNN) -- North Korean leader Kim Jong-il has added his brother-in-law to a military board in a move analysts say paves the way for an heir, according to South Korea\'s state-sponsored Yonhap news agency.\n\nKim Jong-il has named his brother-in-law Jang Song Thaek to a top military board.\n\nThe addition of his kin to the powerful National Defense Commission also solidifies his standing, Yonhap said.\n\nKim was reappointed Thursday as chairman of the military board in his first major public appearance since a reported stroke in August. His brother-in-law, Jang Song Thaek, is considered his right-hand man, according to Yonhap.\n\nJang, who has been married to Kim\'s sister since 1972, currently serves as a director of the Workers\' Party, Yonhap said.\n\n"Kim wants to keep the military in check and secure loyalty to both the military and the party," Cha Doo-hyeogn, a North Korea expert, told Yonhap.\n\nKim also increased the number of members in the military agency to 13, from eight, Yonhap said.\n\n"Overall, the power of the National Defense Commission was strengthened," Seoul\'s Unification Ministry spokesman, Kim Ho-nyoun, told Yonhap in a briefing.\n\nThere were no other major changes in the new parliament, which signifies that Kim, 67, is prepared to maintain the status quo as he readies someone to take over from him, analysts told Yonhap.\n\nKim\'s recent health problems and long absence from public functions have prompted speculation on whether he is ready to groom an heir to the world\'s only communist dynasty. {'text': 'Khartoum, Sudan (CNN) -- South Sudan\'s government has gained control of a remote town that had been under attack by fighters from a rival tribe, the nation\'s information minister said Monday.\n\n\n\n\n\nSome of the thousands who fled into the bush have begun to return to Pibor, said Barnaba Benjamin, South Sudan\'s minister of information and broadcasting.\n\n\n\n\n\nEarlier Monday, a military official said that roughly 4,000 army and police reinforcements were on the way to Pibor after weekend attacks.\n\n\n\n\n\nThe United Nations also said it sent a battalion of peacekeepers to Pibor last week amid reports that members of the Lou Nuer tribe were marching toward the town, home to the Murle tribe, after attacking the village of Lukangol.\n\n\n\n\n\nEthnic tensions in the South Sudan state of Jonglei have flared as tribes fight over grazing lands and water rights, disagreements that have dissolved into cattle raids and abduction of women and children.\n\n\n\n\n\nFighters first struck Pibor on Saturday, attacking a portion that was out of the reach of U.N. peacekeepers, said Col. Philip Auger of the South Sudan army.\n\n\n\n\n\nBenjamin said there were no casualties and no direct confrontation between the two tribes there, because most of the Murle had fled when they heard the Lou Nuer were approaching.\n\n\n\n\n\nThe nonprofit group Medecins sans Frontieres, also known as Doctors Without Borders, was still trying Monday to reach 117 of its 130 aid workers who fled into the bush along with the populations of Pibor and Lukangol before the attack, said Sarathy Rajendran, head of the group\'s South Sudan mission.\n\n\n\n\n\nRajendran said the organization was afraid for its workers\' safety and "very concerned" for the people of Pibor and Lukangol.\n\n\n\n\n\n"We believe tens of thousands are currently displaced without access to water, food and health care," he said. "The situation is tense. We don\'t know what is happening on the ground, so we are monitoring the situation."\n\n\n\n\n\nThe nonprofit\'s clinic in Lukangol was "burned and looted," spokeswoman Emily Linendoll said, adding that its Pibor clinic "has been targeted."\n\n\n\n\n\nThe attack on Pibor follows reports last week that Lou Nuer fighters raided Lukangol, burning it to the ground and forcing thousands to flee toward Pibor.\n\n\n\n\n\nAt least 50,000 people have fled the violence in the state that began last year, said Quade Hermann, chief of radio at Radio Miraya, a U.N.-backed radio station in South Sudan.\n\n\n\n\n\nShe similarly said that the town of Pibor is secure now, though the situation there remains fluid. The people who fled remain scattered, and the United Nations is working on a plan for how to distribute humanitarian aid, Hermann said.\n\n\n\n\n\nU.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon last week urged the groups to work with the government of South Sudan to find solutions.\n\n\n\n\n\nSouth Sudan\'s vice president, Riek Machar, is leading an initiative to bridge the differences between the Lou Nuer and Murle tribes, including encouraging the armed groups to disband and go home, the United Nations has said.\n\n\n\n\n\nThe violence in Jonglei state is the latest to rock South Sudan, which officially gained its statehood in July after separating from the north.', 'qa': [{'question': 'Some have started to return to where?', 'answers': ['Pibor,']}, {'question': 'How many reinforcements were being sent to Pibor?', 'answers': ['4,000 army and police', '4,000', 'roughly 4,000']}, {'question': 'Who were the attackers?', 'answers': ['members of the Lou Nuer tribe']}, {'question': 'Who attacked the town?', 'answers': ['fighters from a rival tribe,', 'by fighters from a rival tribe,']}, {'question': 'How many people fled from Jonglei?', 'answers': ['50,000', 'At least 50,000', 'thousands']}, {'question': 'How many people fled the violence in Jonglei?', 'answers': ['thousands']}, {'question': 'Where did they flee from?', 'answers': ['violence', 'Pibor,']}, {'question': 'Where have they returned to?', 'answers': ['Pibor,']}]}
{'text': 'LAHORE, Pakistan (CNN) -- Angry protests are a common sight in Pakistan. Crowds often gather to denounce the United States or the Pakistani government, which critics accuse of being an American puppet.\n\n\n\n\n\nAntiTaliban protesters in Lahore.\n\n\n\n\n\nBut in the eastern Pakistani city of Lahore this week, several hundred protesters gathered on a scorching day to take on a very different target: the Taliban.\n\n\n\n\n\n"I will fight them to my last breath and the last drop of my blood in my body. I\'m not scared," vowed newspaper publisher Jugnu Mohsin.\n\n\n\n\n\nShe was leading a crowd of several hundred students, artists, writers and others, chanting "the Taliban is the enemy of Islam" in Urdu.\n\n\n\n\n\nPublic protests against the Taliban started cropping up in various Pakistani cities after a video emerged showing militants publicly flogging a teenage girl. The Taliban\'s recent declaration that the Pakistani government and judicial system are "unIslamic" has also outraged many educated Pakistanis.\n\n\n\n\n\nNeha Mehdi moved to Lahore to study. Now, she fears her way of life is being threatened by the Taliban.\n\n\n\n\n\n"I cannot give up my education, and I cannot give up the way I\'m living," the 23-year-old student said. "These Talibans have ruined the reputation of Islam."\n\n\n\n\n\n"There were threats here also from the Taliban that if we gather they might just bomb us," Mehdi said.  Watch how the anti-Taliban movement is growing Â»\n\n\n\n\n\nMore than 250 miles away, Pakistan\'s military continued its assault against Taliban militants who want to impose a radical interpretation of Islamic law in the country\'s northwestern tribal regions.\n\n\n\n\n\nPakistan\'s government recently signed a deal that would allow Islamic law, or sharia, in the tribal belt as long as the law was imposed in accordance with the country\'s constitution.\n\n\n\n\n\nMehdi and others in Lahore fear that the Taliban\'s version of sharia -- which forbids girls from attending school, as well as music, poetry and dance -- is slowly creeping into Lahore, the center of Pakistani culture.\n\n\n\n\n\n"Our way of life is being threatened," said Kamiar Rokni, a fashion designer who took part in the protest. "And if we don\'t do anything about it, then you\'re just going to be sitting around and one day the way you live and what this country\'s all about is going to stand for nothing."\n\n\n\n\n\nRokni said he fears the Taliban "want to change the way we exist."\n\n\n\n\n\nLahore may be hundreds of miles away from the Taliban-held areas outside Islamabad, but it is no stranger to militant attacks.\n\n\n\n\n\n"Last year we lost 39 people in acts of terrorism and this year we have lost 17 people in Lahore alone," Lahore police Chief Parvez Rathore said.\n\n\n\n\n\nAs he speaks, a heavily armed escort is one step behind the police chief even as he walks outside the walls of the city\'s police headquarters.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn March, gunmen attacked a bus carrying the Sri Lankan national cricket team in Lahore, killing six Pakistani police officers and the team\'s driver.\n\n\n\n\n\nWeeks later, militants dressed in police uniforms stormed a police training center in the city, prompting an eight-hour stand-off with police. Eight cadets were killed during the March 30 siege, which the government blamed on Pakistan\'s Taliban.\n\n\n\n\n\nPolice in Lahore said the attacks would not have been possible without local support. Residents say there is no doubt that the Taliban have support in Pakistan\'s second largest city.\n\n\n\n\n\n"They\'re here in Lahore, this is the thing," said Jamal Rahman, who plays guitar for the Lahore-based band, "Lal" which means "Red."\n\n\n\n\n\n"Little groups of the Taliban are going around and intimidating people, causing fear, telling women to cover up and if they don\'t they\'ll shoot them."\n\n\n\n\n\nRahman and his cousin, Aider -- who plays flute for "Lal" -- are using their music to rally society against what he says is a growing threat by the Taliban.\n\n\n\n\n\n"We want to try to get people aware, and try to get people activated and motivated to fight against this militancy," he said.\n\n\n\n\n\nIt is unclear if the protests and rallying cries from Rahman and the others in Lahore are the start of a mass movement or simply the swan song of Pakistan\'s wealthy, urban elite who could be the first to leave if the suicide bombers and insurgents succeed in further destabilizing the country.\n\n\n\n\n\nEither way, their message is a sign that more Pakistanis believe the Taliban\'s threat is directed at them, and not just a reaction to the so-called U.S.-led "war on terror."\n\n\n\n\n\nMehdi said she fears her life as a student could come to a violent end if the people of Lahore do not stand up to Islamic extremists.\n\n\n\n\n\n"If the Taliban take over then I\'ll be on the road being flogged by one of them like they did in Swat and I don\'t want that," she said.\n\n\n\n\n\nSome Pakistanis are resorting to violence to defend their turf.\n\n\n\n\n\nMore than 30 people were killed in the southern port city of Karachi this week as members of the city\'s Mahajir ethnic majority group engaged in deadly clashes with ethnic Pashtuns. The Taliban is a mostly Pashtun movement.\n\n\n\n\n\nThe government in Karachi has issued a "shoot on sight" order to security forces, to try to maintain calm in the city.\n\n\n\n\n\nA week before the clashes erupted, a leader of the MQM political party, which represents the Mahajir community in Karachi, said his supporters would fight back against what he called the "Talibanization" of his city.\n\n\n\n\n\n"You have to take the nasty decisions now," Haider Abbas Rizvi told CNN last week. "You have to take effective measures to control these Taliban ...otherwise the Taliban will take over."', 'qa': [{'question': 'What were the protests against?', 'answers': ['the Taliban.', 'the Taliban']}, {'question': 'what did the residents say', 'answers': ["there is no doubt that the Taliban have support in Pakistan's second largest city.", "no doubt that the Taliban have support in Pakistan's second largest city."]}, {'question': 'what are they afraid of', 'answers': ['Taliban "want to change the way we exist."', 'her way of life is being threatened by the Taliban.']}, {'question': 'Where is the Taliban exerting influence?', 'answers': ['Pakistan.', 'Lahore,']}, {'question': 'Where did the protests occur?', 'answers': ['Pakistan.']}, {'question': 'what happened in lahore', 'answers': ['several hundred protesters gathered', 'protesters', "killing six Pakistani police officers and the team's driver.", 'gunmen attacked a bus carrying the Sri Lankan national cricket team']}, {'question': 'Where are the protests?', 'answers': ['Pakistan.']}]}
{'text': '(CNN) -- Fans of the character Easy Rawlins don\'t want to hear it, but author Walter Mosley says he has officially moved on.\n\nAuthor Walter Mosley found fame with his Easy Rawlins mysteries and has debuted a new series.\n\nThe prolific writer seemingly wrapped up his beloved series -- which spawned the 1995 film "Devil in a Blue Dress" starring Denzel Washington -- in 2007 with the 10th Easy Rawlins mystery, "Blonde Faith."\n\nThe ending saddened die-hard fans who had faithfully followed the adventures of the Los Angeles, California-based everyman-turned-private investigator whose stories played out in an era from the Jim Crow 1940s to the politically charged 1960s.\n\nNow Mosley, who has found success writing everything from erotica to science fiction, has launched a new mystery series with the release of his book "The Long Fall" (Riverhead).\n\nThe book features an ex-boxer named Leonid Trotter McGill, the latest colorfully named Mosley character. Three of his previous books involved ex-convict Socrates Fortlow, and another trio concerned bookseller Paris Minton.\n\nBut the new novel takes Mosley to a different place and time. Instead of mid-20th century Los Angeles, "The Long Fall" is set in modern-day New York, where McGill is finding it hard to leave his less-than-stellar past behind.\n\nThat past includes a childhood as a red-diaper baby abandoned by his union organizer father and left to fend for himself at an early age, a loveless marriage to an unfaithful woman named Katrina and a son who\'s a burgeoning criminal mastermind.\n\nMoreover, he\'s at work on a case where you just know people are going to die.\n\nSuch page turners are nothing new for Mosley, who is known for his strong, black male characters and his passionate musings on race, politics and the writing life.\n\nMcGill\'s creator recently spoke with CNN about the new mystery novel, why he doesn\'t miss Easy, and how the changes in the United States are mirrored in his writing. The following is an edited version of the interview.\n\nCNN: Why leave Los Angeles for a setting in modern-day New York?\n\nWalter Mosley: I have been a resident of both cities. The new series being contemporary and about a character who in some murky ways reflects where America is right now, New York seemed the right place for that.\n\nCNN: How so? Where do you think America is right now?\n\nMosley: I think that America has made a decision, after about 20 years of going in one direction, to go in another direction: to leave rampant and amoral kind of deregulation and also rampant and immoral wars and say, "Maybe we should be doing the right thing instead of the wrong thing," or redefining what the right thing is, at any rate.\n\nThose kinds of decisions, there are only two places [the setting] can be, and that\'s either in Washington, D.C., which I feel is very limiting because it\'s a one-business town, or New York, where everything from economics to government is centered.\n\nSo I decided on New York.\n\nCNN: McGill is trying to leave behind his shady past. Do you feel like America is trying to do the same?\n\nMosley: Yes, I think that\'s exactly what\'s happening. I think America is trying to seek redemption after having done many things wrong in the eyes of the world in general.\n\nLeonid McGill is trying to seek redemption after a long criminal history. His history is somewhat forgivable, but still it\'s criminal.\n\nCNN: Did you approach this book differently than you did when you were writing the Easy Rawlins mysteries?\n\nMosley: Yes and no. All books are different, so each of the Easy Rawlins books I wrote I approached differently. [Leonid] is a new character and he has a unique life that I had to begin to learn. I knew Easy very well, but Leonid I had to learn who he was.\n\nCNN: In your new book, I love that McGill\'s wife\'s name is "Katrina" and she leaves lots of destruction in her wake.\n\nMosley: [chuckling] It\'s true, but the first story I wrote about Leonid [a story called "Karma" published in the anthology "Dangerous Women"] was before the hurricane and that was a long time ago. It\'s funny that it worked out like that.\n\nCNN: What do you like about McGill?\n\nMosley: This is the first time in my experiments in crime fiction that I\'ve written a hard-boiled detective character. This is going all the way back to the beginning of the genre in the \'30s, where you have a guy who gets thumped upside the head a lot and he\'s just as bad as the people he\'s after.\n\nIn the old style, you never knew what was going on inside the hard-boiled character\'s head, but in these stories I am actually discovering the underlying character of the hard-boiled detective, and for me that\'s been a great deal of fun.\n\nCNN: You\'ve written so many various genres. What is it about the genre of crime fiction that appeals to you?\n\nMosley: Originally I got into it because you can talk about worlds that people wouldn\'t read about ordinarily unless they had a particular interest in it. Everybody reads crime fiction and they read it to find out about different worlds.\n\nI like writing in different genres. There\'s all this stuff that I really enjoy doing because I think they all serve different purposes.\n\nAnd listen, I\'m known as a crime writer, people like it and I enjoy it.\n\nCNN: For your fans, a lot of them miss Easy Rawlins. Do you miss him at all?\n\nMosley: No, he\'s right there on the shelf. All I have to do is reach up and pull him down.\n\nI\'m finished with that. {'text': '(CNN) -- Scotland\'s Susan Boyle gives new meaning to the term "overnight sensation." The "Britain\'s Got Talent" contestant was expected to be something of a joke when she first sauntered on stage, but she absolutely wowed the audience, the judges -- and then the world via the Internet -- with her stunning rendition of "I Dreamed a Dream."\n\n\n\nAlong with Simon Cowell and Piers Morgan, Amanda Holden is a judge on "Britain\'s Got Talent."\n\n\n\nBut like others who stumble upon sudden fame, she found the pressure and scrutiny to be overwhelming.\n\n\n\n"Talent" judge Amanda Holden and Dr. Drew Pinsky of VH1\'s "Celebrity Rehab With Dr. Drew" joined CNN\'s Larry King Tuesday night to discuss Boyle\'s hospitalization for stress and the toll the spotlight and media criticism might have taken on her mental health. They also discussed whether Boyle will develop the emotional stamina for a high-pressure singing career.\n\n\n\nThe following interview has been edited for brevity and clarity:\n\n\n\nLarry King: What do we know right now?\n\n\n\nAmanda Holden: Basically, we\'ve spoken to Susan\'s brother. He, in fact, spoke on [CBS\' "The Early Show"] this morning to say that his sister was very keen to come home as soon as she possibly could and that she was resting up in a clinic in London and that she was very much looking forward to coming out and seeing what was available to her when she felt better.\n\n\n\nKing: Is the show, Amanda, paying for the hospital bills and are they taking care of her?\n\n\n\nHolden: I have no idea if they\'re paying the hospital bills. I would imagine that they are. We\'re a very loyal show. We love Susan very much. In fact, all the contestants that appear on our show are extraordinarily well looked after.\n\n\n\nKing: Your fellow judge, Piers Morgan, has said that there was talk of taking her off the show because of all the pressures on her. Were you involved? Were there any discussions like that?\n\n\n\nHolden: I wasn\'t involved in any discussions like that. And I think Piers has a slightly closer relationship with her.  ... The only thing I\'m worried about with Susan Boyle is that she seems to have a crush on Piers Morgan. ...\n\n\n\nI think that Piers kind of reassured her during the final that she was doing well and that she mustn\'t pay any kind of attention to the press and all the other stuff that was going\n\n\n\nKing: Despite all the tumult, there\'s no disputing that Susan sang her heart out during the finale of the competition. I know the dance troupe [Diversity] was terrific. But, frankly, why didn\'t she win?\n\n\n\nHolden: Honestly, I can\'t criticize the decision because it was the British public that voted in the end. I have no real idea, to be honest. I wonder whether it could be that Diversity was utterly fantastic on the show that night. They decimated the show. They really, really were amazing. And I just wonder whether maybe younger people voted and were quicker on the texts than the kind of people that were voting for Susan.\n\n\n\nBut as I keep saying, if Susan is a loser, then surely she is the biggest and best loser that we have in the world. And coming second is no bad thing.  Watch Amanda Holden discuss Susan Boyle Â»\n\n\n\nKing: She came in, though, [as] a small-town amateur singer, [with] learning disabilities due to suffering oxygen deprivation at birth. Some say the program exploited her and her vulnerabilities. Do you agree?\n\n\n\nHolden: I couldn\'t disagree more. You know, she\'s a grown woman who applied to come on a talent show. She enjoyed every second of every moment that I met her or saw her behind the scenes. She was very excited. She was very proud to be taking part in the show.\n\n\n\nI think the downturn in press in our country [Britain], I think, maybe stressed her out a little bit. And I think she was just quite upset about all the exaggerated stories and the kind of falsehoods that were being written about her. I think that everybody gets upset about bad press when you\'re in this business. And she\'s somebody that\'s gone from anonymity to [an] absolute worldwide phenomenon.\n\n\n\nKing: Yes.\n\n\n\nHolden: So how is she expected to handle that? Nobody can handle that with the best will in the world. I\'ve been in the business 15 years, and I\'m still not media savvy.\n\n\n\n[Dr. Drew Pinsky joins the show]\n\n\n\nKing: What do you make of this Susan Boyle thing?\n\n\n\nPinsky: The problem here is that here\'s a woman that\'s suddenly under the scrutiny of the spotlight who maybe has some  developmental issues, who is under tremendous stress and [now] is in a psychiatric hospital. The question is, did the show harm her?\n\n\n\nKing: Did it?\n\n\n\nPinsky: It\'s hard to say. This is the first time these kind of experiences have really been undertaken by people. People that come out of nowhere all of a sudden are international superstars.\n\n\n\nKing: Should we be, Amanda, concerned about that?\n\n\n\nHolden: First of all, I just want to say that Susan\'s brother said on British television this morning that, yes, Susan has experienced learning difficulties. But in actual fact, when she was at school, she did as well as any of her other siblings. But throughout her childhood, always before an exam or anything else, she always got quite anxious.\n\n\n\n[Before the show], she was feeling nervous. But she went out there and she nailed it. You know, she did the best performance that we\'ve seen. And let\'s not forget, this is actually only the second or third time we\'ve heard her sing. ...\n\n\n\nShe is in a place where celebrities go when they are burnt out. Now, I am obviously not a doctor. I have no factual information to give to you. I can only say to you her brother ... has said she wants to come home within a matter of days, rather than weeks.\n\n\n\nPinsky: That\'s excellent.\n\n\n\nKing: Would you guess, Dr. Drew, that she still has a career in front of her? Wouldn\'t you bet she does?\n\n\n\nPinsky: Oh, I bet she does, absolutely. And she will learn to become accustomed to this kind of stress, I am sure. But let\'s make sure she has the care she needs.\n\n\n\nAnd let\'s be sure that ... everybody that goes on shows like this has access to things that help them deal with the stress of these kinds of environments.', 'qa': [{'question': 'What does Holden beleive?', 'answers': ["have no idea if they're paying the hospital bills. {'text': '(CNN) -- It\'s all tied up in Texas.\n\n\n\nSens. Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama are running a tight race in Texas.\n\n\n\nA new CNN/Opinion Research Corp. poll suggests the battle for the Democratic presidential nomination between Sens. Hillary Clinton of New York and Barack Obama of Illinois is a statistical dead heat in Texas, which holds primaries March 4.\n\n\n\nIn the survey, out Monday, 50 percent of likely Democratic primary voters support Clinton as their choice for the party\'s nominee, with 48 percent backing Obama.\n\n\n\nBut taking into account the poll\'s sampling error of plus or minus 4Â½ percentage points for Democratic respondents, the race is a virtual tie.  Watch Democrats target Texas. Â»\n\n\n\nTwo recent polls by other organizations also show the race statistically even. Map: National and state polling\n\n\n\n"One reason the race appears to be tight is that Texas Democrats are having a hard time choosing between two attractive options," says CNN polling director Keating Holland.\n\n\n\n"Likely Democratic primary voters would be equally happy if either candidate won the nomination, and they don\'t see a lot of difference between them on several top issues.\n\n\n\n"Roughly a quarter of likely voters say they could change their minds in the next two weeks -- and not surprisingly, those people are splitting roughly equally between Clinton and Obama."\n\n\n\nMany political strategists and analysts consider Texas and Ohio -- which also holds a March 4 primary -- must-win states for Clinton. Obama has won the past eight contests and is now ahead in the overall battle for delegates, 193 of which are at stake in Texas.\n\n\n\nThe new survey indicates Arizona Sen. John McCain is the clear favorite for the Republican presidential nomination.\n\n\n\nAmong Republicans, 55 percent of likely Texas GOP primary voters support McCain as their choice for nominee. Thirty-two percent back former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee and 11 percent support home-state congressman and former Libertarian standard-bearer Ron Paul. The poll\'s sampling error for Republican respondents is 4 percentage points.\n\n\n\nThe CNN/Opinion Research Corp. poll was conducted by telephone from Friday through Sunday. Pollsters talked to 1,506 adults in Texas, including 553 likely Republican primary voters and 529 likely Democratic primary voters.\n\n\n\nMcCain is the overwhelming front-runner in the fight for the Republican presidential nomination and party leaders have rallied around the candidate in an attempt for party unity.\n\n\n\nThe poll was released on the same day the only living former Republican president -- George Herbert Walker Bush, the current president\'s father -- endorsed McCain at an event in Houston.  Watch McCain get a big boost Â»\n\n\n\nBut McCain has had trouble winning conservative voters. Just last week, McCain lost the conservative vote to Huckabee in the Virginia primary, according to exit polls. The new survey, though, suggests McCain may have better luck in Texas.\n\n\n\n"It looks like McCain has made some inroads with conservative Republicans," Holland said.\n\n\n\n"McCain is picking up a bare majority among conservative likely voters in the GOP primary. The McCain campaign probably wishes that number were higher, but it does mean that a McCain victory in Texas would not be based on the votes of moderates and independents, as has happened in several states in the past few weeks."\n\n\n\nTexas Democrats and Republicans may not see eye to eye on the issues, but the poll suggests they do agree on what\'s the most important issue. Thirty-five percent of Democrats and an equal number of Republicans said the economy was the most important issue in their choice for president.\n\n\n\nThe second most important issue for Democrats was health care, at 23 percent, followed by the war in Iraq at 22 percent, illegal immigration at 10 percent and terrorism at 7 percent.\n\n\n\nNineteen percent of Republicans said illegal immigration was their most important issue, putting it in second place, followed by the war in Iraq and terrorism at 17 percent and health care at 8 percent.\n\n\n\nSixty percent of Republicans say they\'ll definitely support the candidate they are now backing. That number climbs to 76 percent for Democrats.\n\n\n\nLikely Democratic primary voters view Clinton and Obama on roughly equal terms. Seventy-nine percent say they would be satisfied if Clinton were the nominee; an equal number feel the same way about Obama. Seventy-nine percent say it\'s likely Clinton can win the nomination; 82 percent say the same about Obama.\n\n\n\nThe two candidates are essentially tied on immigration, Iraq and the economy, but Clinton has an advantage on health care and abortion. {'text': '(CNN) -- Bayern Munich have agreed a deal to sign Croatian international striker Ivica Olic from Bundesliga rivals Hamburg, the German champions have revealed on their official Web site fcbayern.de.\n\n\n\nOlic will join Bayern Munich at the end of the season after proving a success in his time at Hamburg.\n\n\n\n"We\'ve struck an agreement to sign Olic at the end of the season. All we need now are the signatures under the contract," said Bayern general manager Uli Hoeness following the team\'s arrival at a winter training camp in Dubai.\n\n\n\nOlic will complete his move on a free transfer on July 1 and will sign a three-year contract binding him to the club until 2012.\n\n\n\n"I\'ll do everything I can to mark my departure from Hamburg with a trophy," the 29-year-old Olic vowed on Friday, as he and his team-mates prepared for a winter training camp almost exactly parallel to Bayern\'s in Dubai.\n\n\n\nThe two teams will meet on January 30 in Hamburg in a match marking the official start of the second half of the Bundesliga season.\n\n\n\nOlic joined Hamburg from CSKA Moscow in January 2007 having won three league titles and the UEFA Cup in Russia. He has already scored 12 goals this season and has netted 11 times in 61 internationals for Croatia.\n\n\n\n"We\'re certain Ivica will be a perfect compliment to our strikers Luca Toni and Miroslav Klose. {'text': 'ATHENS, Georgia (CNN)  -- A University of Georgia professor apparently shot and killed his wife and two other people at a community theater group\'s reunion Saturday, then dropped the couple\'s two children off at a neighbor\'s and fled.\n\n\n\n\n\nAn alert on the UGA Web site says professor George Zinkhan  is a suspect in an off-campus shooting.\n\n\n\n\n\nAthens-Clarke County police said they have local, regional and national alerts out for George Zinkhan, 57, an endowed marketing professor at the school\'s Terry College of Business.\n\n\n\n\n\n"It appeared he and his wife were having problems," police Capt. Clarence Holeman said.\n\n\n\n\n\nHoleman identified the dead as Marie Bruce, 47, Zinkhan\'s wife and a prominent Athens attorney; Tom Tanner, 40; and Ben Teague, 63.\n\n\n\n\n\nFriends identified Bruce as the president of the board of the Town and Gown Players, the theater group holding a reunion picnic on the theater\'s deck when the shooting took place. Tanner and Teague were identified as set designers for the theater.\n\n\n\n\n\nTwo other people were wounded by ricocheting bullets, Holeman said, but did not identify them. At least 20 people were in attendance at the event, he said.\n\n\n\n\n\nZinkhan was not at the theater event initially, Holeman said, but when he arrived, he got into "a disagreement" with his wife. He left the scene -- police believe to his car, where his children were waiting -- and returned with two handguns.\n\n\n\n\n\n"It only took a few minutes," Holeman said. Police found eight shell casings, he said.\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter the shootings, Zinkhan left the scene with his two children -- ages 8 and 10 -- still in the vehicle, police said. He drove to a neighbor\'s home in nearby Bogart, Georgia, where he lived, and left the children there.\n\n\n\n\n\nThe neighbor, Bob Covington, told CNN that Zinkhan arrived at his home shortly after noon with the two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n"He rang the doorbell -- asked me if I could keep his kids for about an hour," Covington said. "I said sure, and he said there\'d been some type of emergency, and he took off."\n\n\n\n\n\nZinkhan seemed hurried and agitated but that seemed consistent with an emergency, Covington said. He didn\'t question Zinkhan about the emergency, Covington said, adding that it wasn\'t unusual for someone in his family to watch the children.\n\n\n\n\n\nAn hour or so later, he said, police arrived and took the children.\n\n\n\n\n\nCovington described Zinkhan as "a very quiet guy, but family-oriented."\n\n\n\n\n\n"He was great around his kids," he said. "Never saw a bit of a problem between he his wife or his kids."\n\n\n\n\n\nCovington said he was "completely shocked, didn\'t believe it" when he heard the news, and said he knew Marie Bruce much better than her husband.\n\n\n\n\n\n"She was much more talkative, very vivacious," he said.\n\n\n\n\n\nPolice Maj. Mike Shockley told CNN that officers were searching Zinkhan\'s home Saturday and that a wide search for the suspect was in progress.\n\n\n\n\n\n"It\'s still a hunt," he said. " ... Now it\'s just a matter of trying to locate him."\n\n\n\n\n\nHoleman said Zinkhan has relatives in Texas and owns a home in Amsterdam, The Netherlands. He was last seen driving a red, 2005 Jeep Liberty, Holeman said.\n\n\n\n\n\nThe news reverberated across Athens.\n\n\n\n\n\n"The University community is shocked and saddened at this tragic event," University of Georgia President Michael F. Adams, said in a written statement. "Our first thoughts are for safety of the university community and for prompt apprehension of the person responsible. Our thoughts and prayers are with the families of all those who have been affected."\n\n\n\n\n\nAnother university professor, Steve Elliott-Gower, told CNN that Zinkhan had been at the school for at least 10 years and was "a distinguished professor with a national reputation."\n\n\n\n\n\n"He was quirky and aloof, but absolutely nothing that I saw would lead me to this conclusion," said the professor. Elliott-Gower said he didn\'t know Zinkhan well, but knew him through Zinkhan\'s wife who, like Elliott-Gower, was associated with the theater.\n\n\n\n\n\n"There are generations of people in the Athens community that have been involved in the theater," he said. "It\'s really difficult to imagine how an organization which is this close-knit recovers from something like this."\n\n\n\n\n\nTown and Gown Players\' Web site said its present production, "Sherlock Holmes: The Final Adventure," is canceled.\n\n\n\n\n\nCNN\'s Divina Mims contributed to this report.', 'qa': [{'question': 'What is the age of the wife?', 'answers': ['47,']}, {'question': 'Who was wife of suspect?', 'answers': ['Marie Bruce,']}, {'question': 'what was the crime', 'answers': ['an off-campus shooting.', 'shot and killed his wife and', 'killed his wife and', 'shot', 'two other people']}, {'question': 'What is the age of the suspect?', 'answers': ['57,']}, {'question': 'how many victums were there', 'answers': ['other', 'people', 'wounded by ricocheting', 'Two other people', 'two other people', 'his wife and', 'bullets,', 'two']}, {'question': 'What did suspect do with children?', 'answers': ["off at a neighbor's and fled.", "off at a neighbor's", 'off-campus shooting.', "dropped the couple's two"]}, {'question': 'Who are alerts out for?', 'answers': ['George Zinkhan,']}, {'question': 'What is number of identified victims?', 'answers': ['two other people', 'his wife and']}]}
{'text': "Editor's note: We asked readers to weigh in on CNN.com Live producer Jarrett Bellini's vacation destination, and you chose South Africa. Check back for updates on his trip.\n\n\n\nCNN.com's Jarrett Bellini tours vineyards outside Cape Town, South Africa.\n\n\n\nCAPE TOWN, South Africa (CNN) -- I'm not a wine drinker.\n\n\n\nBefore today's excursion, in fact, I could only tell you that on the face of the planet there existed three types of wine: red, white and Carlo Rossi.  The reds are good with meat.  The whites go with fish.  And, according to what I learned from my dad, Carlo Rossi goes with a glass of ice.\n\n\n\nSo, exploring South Africa's wine country, just a short drive from Cape Town, seemed like a perfect educational way for me to spend my day.  I mean, it was that or go to a museum.\n\n\n\nOur guide, Jack, was amazingly knowledgeable about the subject, but without being a pretentious jerk.  Really, as far as he is concerned, the best wine in the world is whatever wine you enjoy.  I didn't ask, but was curious if that applied to Boone's Farm?\n\n\n\nThroughout the day, we hit four wineries, tasting 23 bottles in all.  I know because I kept hash marks on my hand.  I'm pretty classy.\n\n\n\nNow, despite the outstanding info we received from our guide as we sipped and swirled and spat, I can't say that I'm any better at understanding the finer points of wine than I was this morning when I woke up.  However, I did manage to get a solid buzz.  And that should be worth something.\n\n\n\nEven without the wine, a visit to South Africa's vineyards is a great addition to a traveler's to-do list. {'text': '(CNN) -- A Seattle man has been charged with insurance fraud for allegedly sinking his own yacht because of "financial pressure and frustration with the maintenance" of the vessel, authorities said.\n\nThe Jubilee sank in Puget Sound Bay last year.\n\nOn March 22, 2008, Brian Lewis, 50, scuttled the Jubilee in the Puget Sound Bay, then rowed a borrowed dinghy back to shore, according to court documents filed in February by prosecutors in King County, Washington.\n\nLater that day, Lewis boarded a flight to take him to his job in Kodiak, Alaska, as a petty officer with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, according to court documents.\n\nThree days later, Lewis filed an insurance claim with USAA Insurance reporting the Jubilee sank accidentally "due to unknown causes."\n\nHowever, due to environmental concerns, the Washington State Department of Natural Resources salvaged the vessel at a cost to the state of $2,866.\n\nAn inspection found a hole was drilled into the bottom of the Jubilee, and that two main engine sea strainers appeared to have been broken with a hammer.\n\n"The vessel appeared to have been deliberately sunk," authorities said in their probable cause affidavit.\n\nConfronted by investigators, Lewis admitted he intentionally sank his vessel, saying the financial strain "caused him extreme anxiety and frustration."\n\nLewis told investigators "the engine trouble he experienced caused him to lose his temper. In his rage, he smashed the sea strainers with a hammer and drilled the hole to sink the vessel," the affidavit said.\n\n"[He] wanted to clarify that his motive for sinking the vessel was anger and frustration, not greed," it added.\n\nPrior to its sinking, the Jubilee had been listed for sale with Mahina Yachts for $28,500.\n\nJack Bateman, a broker with Mahina, remembers the Jubilee as a "beautiful" 1967 Chris Craft Cavalier. He said the Mahina has only seen this type of case one other time in its 30 years of operation.\n\n"This is a very rare, not common occurrence" he says. Bateman added that Mahina has yet to see any real distress sales due to the bad economy.\n\nThe King County Prosecutor\'s Office has charged Lewis with making a fraudulent insurance claim.\n\nLewis filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy in 2004. Messages left for him were not returned.', 'qa': [{'question': 'who filed claim due to unknown causes?', 'answers': ['Lewis']}, {'question': 'Is it illegal to sink your own boat?', 'answers': ['Seattle man has been charged with insurance fraud for allegedly sinking his', 'yacht']}, {'question': 'Who filed the fraudulent claim?', 'answers': ['Lewis']}, {'question': 'What has Brian Lewis been charged with?', 'answers': ['insurance fraud']}, {'question': 'what were filed against Seattle man?', 'answers': ['insurance fraud']}, {'question': 'what did he do to the yacht?', 'answers': ['sinking', 'sinking his own']}, {'question': 'Where was the boat stolen?', 'answers': ['Puget Sound Bay']}, {'question': 'what was discovered in inspection?', 'answers': ['drilled into the bottom of the Jubilee,', 'a hole']}]}
{'text': "(CNN) -- Two people were killed and two were severely wounded Tuesday in a shooting at a courthouse in Landshut, Germany, police said.\n\nA police car sits outside the courthouse in the German city of Landshut.\n\nThe gunman, a 60-year-old man, was among the dead, Bavarian Police said in a statement.\n\nIt happened around 10:15 a.m. (4:15 a.m. ET) during a break in a court proceeding about inheritance, Landshut police spokesman Leonard Mayer told CNN.\n\nThe man began shooting once he stepped outside the courtroom, police said.\n\nHe wounded three people before turning the gun on himself, Mayer said. One of the victims, a woman, died about 2 1/2 hours later, Bavarian Police said.
